elements.content: The reaction between Cs3[Mo(CN)8]·2H2O and MnCl2·4H2O gives two new cyano-bridged bimetallic compounds of ([Mn2 II(H2O)2(CH3COO)][MoV(CN)8]·2H2O)n (1) and ([Mn2 II(H2O)3Cl][MoV(CN)8]·4H2O)n (2) in different conditions. The magnetic behaviors of these complexes have been investigated, indicating that 1 is a ferrimagnet with an ordering temperature of about 6 K and that for 2 there is antiferromagnetic coupling between the paramagnetic ions in the system.

The magnetic behaviors of these complexes have been investigated, indicating that 1 is a ferrimagnet with an ordering temperature of about 6 K and that for 2 there is antiferromagnetic coupling between the paramagnetic ions in the system.

elements.content:
Two new MoV−MnII analogues have been designed and synthesized, in which 1 is a ferrimagnet with Tc about 6 K, while 2 is antifrromagnetic coupling.

Introduction

There has been great interest in the preparation of molecule-based magnets in recent years. The hexacyanometalate ions, acting as good building units, have been successfully utilized to obtain a large number of one-, two-, and three-dimensional cyano-bridged assemblies with high magnetic ordering temperature and interesting architectures. Recently, octacyanometallate-based magnets have also drawn much attention. [MV(CN)8]3− (M = Mo and W) is a versatile class of building blocks that can adopt different spatial configurations, just as square antiprism (D 4d), dodecahedron (D 2d), bicapped trigonal prism (C 2v). Because of enhanced exchange interaction in bimetallic compounds based on the larger extension of 4d or 5d magnetic orbitals, [MV(CN)8]3− (M = Mo and W) is a kind of good precursor in magnetic materials. Following the pioneering work of Kahn’s group, these flexible species may be used as versatile synthons to construct a variety of architectures or networks with novel topological structures and interesting magnetic properties. For example, MV-MnII, MV-CuII, MV-CoII, MV-NiII, and MV 6MnII 9 (a few multinuclear clusters) (M = Mo and W) bimetallic assemblies with a variety of extended structure have been obtained. However, only four examples based on [MoV(CN)8]3− and MnII ions as ([MnII(bipy)(DMF)2]2[MoV(CN)8]2[MnII(DMF)4])n, [MnII(DMF)4]3[Mo(CN)8]2, [MnII(MnII(MeOH)3)8(μ-CN)30(MoV(CN)3)6·5MeOH·2H2O, and [MnII(MnII(MeOH)3)8(μ-CN)30(MoV(CN)3)6·0.5MeOH·6H2O have been studied structurally and magnetically so far. Therefore, to better understand the magnetic interactions between MoV/MnII couples, the magnetic properties of new structurally characterized MoV−MnII compounds should be investigated. Herein we describe the synthesis, crystal structures, and magnetic properties of two new three-dimensional cyano-bridged coordination polymers, ([Mn2 II(H2O)2(CH3COO)][MoV(CN)8]·2H2O)n (1) and ([Mn2 II(H2O)3Cl][MoV(CN)8]·4H2O)n (2).

elements.content: The precursor Cs3[Mo(CN)8]·2H2O is prepared according to literature methods. All other chemicals are reagent grade and can be used without further purification. Since the octacyanometalate ions have a tendency to decompose under irradiation, the syntheses of the complexes are performed in a dark room at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The precursor Cs3[Mo(CN)8]⋅2H2O is prepared according to literature methods. All other chemicals are reagent grade and can be used without further purification. Since the octacyanometalate ions have a tendency to decompose under irradiation, the syntheses of the complexes are performed in a dark room at room temperature.

elements.content: Single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray crystallography were grown by slow diffusion in a test tube with Cs3[Mo(CN)8]·2H2O (36.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) in glacial acetic acid/water (2:1, 9 mL) as the bottom layer and 6 mL of the MeOH solution containing MnCl2·4H2O (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) as the top layer. After several weeks, well-shaped dark brown square prismatic crystals were obtained. Anal. Calc. for C10H11N8O6Mn2Mo: C, 22.04; H, 2.03; N, 20.56%. Found: C, 22.18; H, 2.25; N, 20.36%. (νC≡N = 2138 cm−1).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[Mn2 II(H2O)2(CH3COO)][MoV(CN)8]⋅2H2O}n (1)

Single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray crystallography were grown by slow diffusion in a test tube with Cs3[Mo(CN)8]⋅2H2O (36.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) in glacial acetic acid/water (2:1, 9 mL) as the bottom layer and 6 mL of the MeOH solution containing MnCl2⋅4H2O (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) as the top layer. After several weeks, well-shaped dark brown square prismatic crystals were obtained. Anal. Calc. for C10H11N8O6Mn2Mo: C, 22.04; H, 2.03; N, 20.56%. Found: C, 22.18; H, 2.25; N, 20.36%. (νC≡N = 2138 cm-1).

elements.content: Single crystals of 2 were grown in a methanol/water/isopropanol solution by a slow diffusion method using an H-shape tube. MnCl2·4H2O (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH/water (2:1, 3 mL) and added to one arm, and Cs3[Mo(CN)8]·2H2O (36.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in water (6 mL) and added to the other one. Then, isopropanol was filled in the tube. Well-shaped yellow crystals, suitable for X-ray determination, were formed after several weeks. Anal. Calc. for C8H14N8O7ClMn2Mo: C, 16.70; H, 2.45; N, 19.47%. Found: C, 16.87; H, 2.45; N, 19.36%. (νC≡N = 2141 cm−1).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[Mn2 II(H2O)3Cl][MoV(CN)8]⋅ 4H2O}n (2)

Single crystals of 2 were grown in a methanol/water/isopropanol solution by a slow diffusion method using an H-shape tube. MnCl2⋅4H2O (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH/water (2:1, 3 mL) and added to one arm, and Cs3[Mo(CN)8]⋅2H2O (36.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in water (6 mL) and added to the other one. Then, isopropanol was filled in the tube. Well-shaped yellow crystals, suitable for X-ray determination, were formed after several weeks. Anal. Calc. for C8H14N8O7ClMn2Mo: C, 16.70; H, 2.45; N, 19.47%. Found: C, 16.87; H, 2.45; N, 19.36%. (νC≡N = 2141 cm-1).

elements.content: Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer elemental analyzer (model 240). The infrared spectra were obtained on a Bruker Tensor 27 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy in the 4000−400 cm−1 regions, using KBr pellets. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a SQUID magnetometer from 2.0 to 300 K in a magnetic field of 2 kOe, and the diamagnetic corrections were applied by using Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer elemental analyzer (model 240). The infrared spectra were obtained on a Bruker Tensor 27 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy in the 4000-400 cm-1 regions, using KBr pellets. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a SQUID magnetometer from 2.0 to 300 K in a magnetic field of 2 kOe, and the diamagnetic corrections were applied by using Pascal's constants.

elements.content: All measurements were made on a Rigaku Saturn CCD or a Bruker Smart 1000 detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The empirical absorption corrections by semiempirical from equivalents were carried out. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-97 program and refined with SHELXL-97 by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, while the hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined isotropically. Further details of the structure analysis are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-Ray Data Collections and Structure Determinations

All measurements were made on a Rigaku Saturn CCD or a Bruker Smart 1000 detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The empirical absorption corrections by semiempirical from equivalents were carried out. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-97 program and refined with SHELXL-97 by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, while the hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined isotropically. Further details of the structure analysis are given in Table .

The reaction between Cs3[Mo(CN)8]·2H2O and MnCl2·4H2O gives two new cyano-bridged bimetallic compounds in different reaction media. These complexes have been fully characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, and X-ray crystallography. The most conspicuous feature of the IR spectra concern the existence of 2138 cm−1 for 1 and 2141 cm−1 for 2, respectively, which may be assigned to the characteristic CN stretching vibrations.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

General Properties

The reaction between Cs3[Mo(CN)8]⋅2H2O and MnCl2⋅4H2O gives two new cyano-bridged bimetallic compounds in different reaction media. These complexes have been fully characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, and X-ray crystallography. The most conspicuous feature of the IR spectra concern the existence of 2138 cm-1 for 1 and 2141 cm-1 for 2, respectively, which may be assigned to the characteristic CN stretching vibrations.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal system, space group I4/mcm with the unit cell constants of a = b = 11.9168(17), c = 13.205(3) Å, β = 90°, and Z = 4. As shown in Figure , this complex reveals a three-dimensional MnII−MoV network, The MnII atoms in the extended structure locate in the center of a distorted octahedron, where four nitrogen atoms from [MoV(CN)8]3− are coplanar with MnII (Mn(1)−N(1), 2.2192(17)Å) forming the equatorial plane, while the apical positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms from one H2O molecule and one disordered acetate anion, respectively, (Mn(1)−O(1) and Mn(1)−O(2) are 2.202(4) and 2.094(4) Å. The bond angle of O(1)−Mn(1)−O(2) in the axis position is 168.98(10)°, and the neighboring MnII ions are bridged by the acetate anion (MnII···MnII distances are 6.2925(8) Å) (Figure a). Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . Every MoV in 1 adopts a square antiprism geometry surrounded by eight cyano groups. (The bond angles of Mo(1)−C(1)−N(1) and Mn(1)−N(1)−C(1) are 177.56(18)° and 164.17(16)°, respectively, and the torsion angle of Mo(1)−C(1)−N(1)−Mn(1) is 56(4)°. A projection of 1 along the a-axis is shown in Figure b; each MoV(CN)8 is surrounded by eight MnII ions, giving an alternately (−Mo-Mn4−)n linkage and forming a three-dimensional arrangement. The Schläfli symbol of this complex net is (6, 8). The shortest distance between MnII and MoV ions is 5.4579(7) Å, and the MoV···MoV and MnII···MnII distances are 6.6025(15) Å and 6.1465(10) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Descriptions

Compound 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal system, space group I4/mcm with the unit cell constants of a = b = 11.9168(17), c = 13.205(3) Å, β = 90°, and Z = 4. As shown in Figure , this complex reveals a three-dimensional MnII-MoV network, The MnII atoms in the extended structure locate in the center of a distorted octahedron, where four nitrogen atoms from [MoV(CN)8]3- are coplanar with MnII (Mn(1)-N(1), 2.2192(17)Å) forming the equatorial plane, while the apical positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms from one H2O molecule and one disordered acetate anion, respectively, (Mn(1)-O(1) and Mn(1)-O(2) are 2.202(4) and 2.094(4) Å. The bond angle of O(1)-Mn(1)-O(2) in the axis position is 168.98(10)°, and the neighboring MnII ions are bridged by the acetate anion (MnII⋅⋅⋅MnII distances are 6.2925(8) Å) (Figure a). Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . Every MoV in 1 adopts a square antiprism geometry surrounded by eight cyano groups. (The bond angles of Mo(1)-C(1)-N(1) and Mn(1)-N(1)-C(1) are 177.56(18)° and 164.17(16)°, respectively, and the torsion angle of Mo(1)-C(1)-N(1)-Mn(1) is 56(4)°. A projection of 1 along the a-axis is shown in Figure b; each MoV(CN)8 is surrounded by eight MnII ions, giving an alternately (-Mo-Mn4-)n linkage and forming a three-dimensional arrangement. The Schläfli symbol of this complex net is (6, 8). The shortest distance between MnII and MoV ions is 5.4579(7) Å, and the MoV⋅⋅⋅MoV and MnII⋅⋅⋅MnII distances are 6.6025(15) Å and 6.1465(10) Å, respectively.

For 2, the mainframe is similar to 1, and only several differences are as shown in Figure . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . In 2, MnII ions are all in distorted octahedron geometry with four nitrogen atoms from [MoV(CN)8]3− occupying the equatorial plane [Mn(1)−N(1) = Mn(1)−N(1)#8 (#8 −y+1/2,−x+1/2,z) = Mn(1)−N(1)#9 (#9 x,y,−z) = Mn(1)−N(1)#10 (#10 −y+1/2,−x+1/2,−z+0) = 2.216(7) Å)], while for the axial positions, half of the MnII are coordinated by one oxygen of H2O and a Cl− ion, and the others are coordinated by two oxygens from two H2O (Figure a). The Mn(1)−O(1) and Mn(1)−O(3)#8 = Mn(1)−Cl(1) bond lengths are equal to 2.21(4) and 2.258(18) Å, respectively. These data indicate that complex 2 has two types of MnII centers with different coordination environments, while complex 1 has only one type. The coordination environment of the MoV ion is close to a square antiprism geometry. It is noticed that the bond angle of Mo(1)−C(1)−N(1) is 176.0(9)°, which is close to 180°, while that of Mn(1)−N(1)−C(1) is far from linearity with an angle of 162.1(8)°. The torsion angle of Mo(1)−C(1)−N(1)−Mn(1) is 84.452(97)°. A projection of 2 along the a-axis is shown in Figure b. Each [MoV(CN)8]3− coordinates to eight MnII ions to form a three-dimensional network, and the Schläfli symbol is (4, 8). In addition, the shortest distances of MnII···MoV, MoV···MoV, and MnII−MnII are 5.4576(6), 6.6480(15), and 6.1215(7) Å, respectively. The noncoordinated water molecules in the system occupy the crystalline channels as guest molecules, connected by the coordinated Cl atoms and oxygen atoms through hydrogen-bonds (O(2)···Cl(1), 2.955 Å, O(2)···O(2) (symmetry code: −y+1/2, x-1/2, −z+1/2), 2.918 Å).
elements.clean_text: For 2, the mainframe is similar to 1, and only several differences are as shown in Figure . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . In 2, MnII ions are all in distorted octahedron geometry with four nitrogen atoms from [MoV(CN)8]3- occupying the equatorial plane [Mn(1)-N(1) = Mn(1)-N(1)#8 (#8 -y+1/2,-x+1/2,z) = Mn(1)-N(1)#9 (#9 x,y,-z) = Mn(1)-N(1)#10 (#10 -y+1/2,-x+1/2,-z+0) = 2.216(7) Å)], while for the axial positions, half of the MnII are coordinated by one oxygen of H2O and a Cl- ion, and the others are coordinated by two oxygens from two H2O (Figure a). The Mn(1)-O(1) and Mn(1)-O(3)#8 = Mn(1)-Cl(1) bond lengths are equal to 2.21(4) and 2.258(18) Å, respectively. These data indicate that complex 2 has two types of MnII centers with different coordination environments, while complex 1 has only one type. The coordination environment of the MoV ion is close to a square antiprism geometry. It is noticed that the bond angle of Mo(1)-C(1)-N(1) is 176.0(9)°, which is close to 180°, while that of Mn(1)-N(1)-C(1) is far from linearity with an angle of 162.1(8)°. The torsion angle of Mo(1)-C(1)-N(1)-Mn(1) is 84.452(97)°. A projection of 2 along the a-axis is shown in Figure b. Each [MoV(CN)8]3- coordinates to eight MnII ions to form a three-dimensional network, and the Schläfli symbol is (4, 8). In addition, the shortest distances of MnII⋅⋅⋅MoV, MoV⋅⋅⋅MoV, and MnII-MnII are 5.4576(6), 6.6480(15), and 6.1215(7) Å, respectively. The noncoordinated water molecules in the system occupy the crystalline channels as guest molecules, connected by the coordinated Cl atoms and oxygen atoms through hydrogen-bonds (O(2)⋅⋅⋅Cl(1), 2.955 Å, O(2)⋅⋅⋅O(2) (symmetry code: -y+1/2, x-1/2, -z+1/2), 2.918 Å).

The differences between the crystal structures of the two complexes are as the follows: (i) The coordination environments of the MnII center in two complexes have different deformations. (ii) In 1, the neighboring MnII centers are bridged by acetate anions, while in 2 except for [MoV(CN)8]3−, there are no other bridging ligands for MnII. (iii) As shown in Figure , for the topology structures of both the complexes, 1 belongs to a 3D (6, 8) network (Figure a), while 2 belongs to a 3D (4, 8) network (Figure b).

elements.content: Variable-temperature (2−300 K) magnetic susceptibilities of 1 have been measured on a crystalline sample in a field of 2 kOe. A plot of χ M T vs T is shown in Figure a, where χ M is the molar magnetic susceptibility for the MnII 2MoV unit. The χ M T value at room temperature is 8.78 cm3 mol−1 K (8.38 μB), which is slightly lower than the spin-only value (9.13 cm3 mol−1 K, 8.54 μB) for two high-spin MnII (S = 5/2) and MoV (S = 1/2) centers with g = 2.0, suggesting an antiferromagnetic coupling between MnII and MoV ions. For 1, a shallow minimum is observed at 170 K (see Figure b), suggesting that 1 is likely a ferrimagnet. As the temperature is lowered further, the χ M T product monotonically increases, reaching a maximum of 136.64 cm3 mol−1 K at 6.02 K. Below this temperature, χ M T decreases again, affording a value of 72.32 cm3 mol−1 K at 2.0 K; this is most likely due to the saturation effects. Furthermore, χ M −1 vs T in the range of 300 to 170 K obeys the Curie−Weiss Law [χ M −1 = C/(T − θ)] with a negative Weiss constant θ = −3.02 K, confirming an intramolecular antiferromagnetic interaction between the adjacent MnII and MoV ions. In order to quantitatively understand the spin−exchange interactions between MnII and MoV ions, an approximate expression of the magnetic susceptibility (eq ) in the high temperature range for the MnII−MoV−MnII (S 1 = S 3 = 5/2, S 2 = 1/2) system based on Heisenberg Hamiltonian operation, Ĥ = −2J(Ŝ 1·Ŝ 2 + Ŝ 2·Ŝ 3) − 2J′(Ŝ 1·Ŝ 3) is shown as the following: χ M = N g 2 β 2 k T A B A = 286exp(10y) + 165exp(−11x + 10y) + 165exp(−x) + 84exp(−10x) + 84exp(−2x − 8y) +35exp(−9x −14y) + 35exp(−3x − 14y) + 10exp(−8x −14y) + 10exp(−4x −18y) + exp(−2x−18y) + exp(−5x), and B = 24exp(10y) + 20exp(−11x + 10y) + 20exp(−x) + 16exp(−10x) + 16exp(−2x − 8y) +12exp(−9x −14y) + 12exp(−3x − 14y) + 8exp(−8x −14y) + 8exp(−4x −18y) + 4exp(−2x −18y) + 4exp(−5x), where, x = J/kT, y = J′/kT. As shown in Figure b, the magnetic parameters thus obtained by the simulation of the experimental data (300−200 K) using the above expression are J = −7.28 cm−1, J′ = 0, g = 2.00, and R = 2.67 × 10−7 . The results further prove that there is a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the paramagnetic ions. Figure a shows the field dependence of magnetization. At low fields, the magnetization sharply increased and reached saturation at approximately 30 kOe. The value 9.12 Nβ at 50 kOe is close to the expected magnetization of 9 Nβ for the antiparallel ordering of unpaired electrons of MnII 2MoV, showing the ferrimagnetic nature of complex 1. As shown in the inset of Figure a, compound 1 exhibits a closed hysteresis loop at 2 K with a very small coercive field of less than 10 Oe, indicating that compound 1 is typical of a soft magnet.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of field-cooled and zero-field-cooled magnetization revealed a long-range magnetic ordering of 1 below about 6 K (Figure b). In order to prove the long-range magnetic ordering of 1, temperature dependence of ac susceptibility was measured at 3.5 Oe below 20 K. As shown in Figure c, below about 6 K, the increase of out-of-phase ac susceptibility (χ M ′′) was observed, further proving that the Tc of 1 is about 6 K. The overlap of the unique magnetic orbital of MoV (dz2, assuming Cs symmetry) with dx′y′, dz2′ dx2′-y2′ magnetic orbitals of MnII ion is the most likely situation that favors antiferromagnetic coupling between paramagnetic ions. When comparing the Tc of 1 with that of the similar WV complex [([Mn2 II(H2O)2(CH3COO)][WV(CN)8]·2H2O)n] (Tc = 40 K), we see that the former (Tc = 6 K) is lower than the latter (Tc = 40 K). This might be due to the larger diffusion of 5d orbitals in WV ions than 4d orbitals in MoV ions.

elements.content: Magnetic research for both of the complexes indicate that the two molecules have similar skeleton structure, but present different magnetic properties. For complex 1, the μ-CH3COO− ion as bridging ligand connects two MnII centers resulting in a ferrimagnet, while complex 2 does not show magnetic ordering perhaps because there is no other bridging ligand connecting MnII−MnII except for [MoV(CN)8]3−.

elements.content: In summary, two new cyano-bridged 3d-4d bimetallic complexes, 1 and 2, have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Magnetic studies reveal that 1 is a ferrimagnet with about Tc = 6 K and that complex 2 presents antiferromagnetic coupling between paramagnetic ions. We cannot assess whether this is due to the presence of different groups (μ-CH3COO− and Cl−) or the packing effect in the crystal at this moment. Further studies on these and similar systems should be made to settle this problem.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two new cyano-bridged 3d-4d bimetallic complexes, 1 and 2, have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Magnetic studies reveal that 1 is a ferrimagnet with about Tc = 6 K and that complex 2 presents antiferromagnetic coupling between paramagnetic ions. We cannot assess whether this is due to the presence of different groups (μ-CH3COO- and Cl-) or the packing effect in the crystal at this moment. Further studies on these and similar systems should be made to settle this problem.

cln_elements.content:
Single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray crystallography were grown by slow diffusion in a test tube with Cs3[Mo(CN)8]·2H2O (36.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) in glacial acetic acid/water (2:1, 9 mL) as the bottom layer and 6 mL of the MeOH solution containing MnCl2·4H2O (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) as the top layer. After several weeks, well-shaped dark brown square prismatic crystals were obtained. Anal. Calc. for C10H11N8O6Mn2Mo: C, 22.04; H, 2.03; N, 20.56%. Found: C, 22.18; H, 2.25; N, 20.36%. (νC≡N = 2138 cm−1).

Preparation of {[Mn<sub>2</sub> <sup>II</sup>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>Cl][Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]· 4H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>n</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Single crystals of 2 were grown in a methanol/water/isopropanol solution by a slow diffusion method using an H-shape tube. MnCl2·4H2O (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH/water (2:1, 3 mL) and added to one arm, and Cs3[Mo(CN)8]·2H2O (36.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in water (6 mL) and added to the other one. Then, isopropanol was filled in the tube. Well-shaped yellow crystals, suitable for X-ray determination, were formed after several weeks. Anal. Calc. for C8H14N8O7ClMn2Mo: C, 16.70; H, 2.45; N, 19.47%. Found: C, 16.87; H, 2.45; N, 19.36%. (νC≡N = 2141 cm−1).

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal system, space group I4/mcm with the unit cell constants of a = b = 11.9168(17), c = 13.205(3) Å, β = 90°, and Z = 4. As shown in Figure , this complex reveals a three-dimensional MnII−MoV network, The MnII atoms in the extended structure locate in the center of a distorted octahedron, where four nitrogen atoms from [MoV(CN)8]3− are coplanar with MnII (Mn(1)−N(1), 2.2192(17)Å) forming the equatorial plane, while the apical positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms from one H2O molecule and one disordered acetate anion, respectively, (Mn(1)−O(1) and Mn(1)−O(2) are 2.202(4) and 2.094(4) Å. The bond angle of O(1)−Mn(1)−O(2) in the axis position is 168.98(10)°, and the neighboring MnII ions are bridged by the acetate anion (MnII···MnII distances are 6.2925(8) Å) (Figure a). Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . Every MoV in 1 adopts a square antiprism geometry surrounded by eight cyano groups. (The bond angles of Mo(1)−C(1)−N(1) and Mn(1)−N(1)−C(1) are 177.56(18)° and 164.17(16)°, respectively, and the torsion angle of Mo(1)−C(1)−N(1)−Mn(1) is 56(4)°. A projection of 1 along the a-axis is shown in Figure b; each MoV(CN)8 is surrounded by eight MnII ions, giving an alternately (−Mo-Mn4−)n linkage and forming a three-dimensional arrangement. The Schläfli symbol of this complex net is (6, 8). The shortest distance between MnII and MoV ions is 5.4579(7) Å, and the MoV···MoV and MnII···MnII distances are 6.6025(15) Å and 6.1465(10) Å, respectively.

Magnetic Properties of the Complexes

Variable-temperature (2−300 K) magnetic susceptibilities of 1 have been measured on a crystalline sample in a field of 2 kOe. A plot of χ M T vs T is shown in Figure a, where χ M is the molar magnetic susceptibility for the MnII 2MoV unit. The χ M T value at room temperature is 8.78 cm3 mol−1 K (8.38 μB), which is slightly lower than the spin-only value (9.13 cm3 mol−1 K, 8.54 μB) for two high-spin MnII (S = 5/2) and MoV (S = 1/2) centers with g = 2.0, suggesting an antiferromagnetic coupling between MnII and MoV ions. For 1, a shallow minimum is observed at 170 K (see Figure b), suggesting that 1 is likely a ferrimagnet. As the temperature is lowered further, the χ M T product monotonically increases, reaching a maximum of 136.64 cm3 mol−1 K at 6.02 K. Below this temperature, χ M T decreases again, affording a value of 72.32 cm3 mol−1 K at 2.0 K; this is most likely due to the saturation effects. Furthermore, χ M −1 vs T in the range of 300 to 170 K obeys the Curie−Weiss Law [χ M −1 = C/(T − θ)] with a negative Weiss constant θ = −3.02 K, confirming an intramolecular antiferromagnetic interaction between the adjacent MnII and MoV ions. In order to quantitatively understand the spin−exchange interactions between MnII and MoV ions, an approximate expression of the magnetic susceptibility (eq ) in the high temperature range for the MnII−MoV−MnII (S 1 = S 3 = 5/2, S 2 = 1/2) system based on Heisenberg Hamiltonian operation, Ĥ = −2J(Ŝ 1·Ŝ 2 + Ŝ 2·Ŝ 3) − 2J′(Ŝ 1·Ŝ 3) is shown as the following: χ M = N g 2 β 2 k T A B A = 286exp(10y) + 165exp(−11x + 10y) + 165exp(−x) + 84exp(−10x) + 84exp(−2x − 8y) +35exp(−9x −14y) + 35exp(−3x − 14y) + 10exp(−8x −14y) + 10exp(−4x −18y) + exp(−2x−18y) + exp(−5x), and B = 24exp(10y) + 20exp(−11x + 10y) + 20exp(−x) + 16exp(−10x) + 16exp(−2x − 8y) +12exp(−9x −14y) + 12exp(−3x − 14y) + 8exp(−8x −14y) + 8exp(−4x −18y) + 4exp(−2x −18y) + 4exp(−5x), where, x = J/kT, y = J′/kT. As shown in Figure b, the magnetic parameters thus obtained by the simulation of the experimental data (300−200 K) using the above expression are J = −7.28 cm−1, J′ = 0, g = 2.00, and R = 2.67 × 10−7 . The results further prove that there is a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the paramagnetic ions. Figure a shows the field dependence of magnetization. At low fields, the magnetization sharply increased and reached saturation at approximately 30 kOe. The value 9.12 Nβ at 50 kOe is close to the expected magnetization of 9 Nβ for the antiparallel ordering of unpaired electrons of MnII 2MoV, showing the ferrimagnetic nature of complex 1. As shown in the inset of Figure a, compound 1 exhibits a closed hysteresis loop at 2 K with a very small coercive field of less than 10 Oe, indicating that compound 1 is typical of a soft magnet.

Conclusions

In summary, two new cyano-bridged 3d-4d bimetallic complexes, 1 and 2, have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Magnetic studies reveal that 1 is a ferrimagnet with about Tc = 6 K and that complex 2 presents antiferromagnetic coupling between paramagnetic ions. We cannot assess whether this is due to the presence of different groups (μ-CH3COO− and Cl−) or the packing effect in the crystal at this moment. Further studies on these and similar systems should be made to settle this problem.

Structural Descriptions

Compound 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal system, space group I4/mcm with the unit cell constants of a = b = 11.9168(17), c = 13.205(3) Å, β = 90°, and Z = 4. As shown in Figure , this complex reveals a three-dimensional MnII-MoV network, The MnII atoms in the extended structure locate in the center of a distorted octahedron, where four nitrogen atoms from [MoV(CN)8]3- are coplanar with MnII (Mn(1)-N(1), 2.2192(17)Å) forming the equatorial plane, while the apical positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms from one H2O molecule and one disordered acetate anion, respectively, (Mn(1)-O(1) and Mn(1)-O(2) are 2.202(4) and 2.094(4) Å. The bond angle of O(1)-Mn(1)-O(2) in the axis position is 168.98(10)°, and the neighboring MnII ions are bridged by the acetate anion (MnII⋅⋅⋅MnII distances are 6.2925(8) Å) (Figure a). Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . Every MoV in 1 adopts a square antiprism geometry surrounded by eight cyano groups. (The bond angles of Mo(1)-C(1)-N(1) and Mn(1)-N(1)-C(1) are 177.56(18)° and 164.17(16)°, respectively, and the torsion angle of Mo(1)-C(1)-N(1)-Mn(1) is 56(4)°. A projection of 1 along the a-axis is shown in Figure b; each MoV(CN)8 is surrounded by eight MnII ions, giving an alternately (-Mo-Mn4-)n linkage and forming a three-dimensional arrangement. The Schläfli symbol of this complex net is (6, 8). The shortest distance between MnII and MoV ions is 5.4579(7) Å, and the MoV⋅⋅⋅MoV and MnII⋅⋅⋅MnII distances are 6.6025(15) Å and 6.1465(10) Å, respectively.

metadata.title:
A New Bimetallic Ferrimagnet ([Mn2
II(H2O)2(CH3COO)][MoV(CN)8]·2H2O)n and Its Antiferromagnetic Analogue ([Mn2
II(H2O)3Cl][MoV(CN)8]·4H2O)n

Cyano-Bridged 3d-4d Bimetallic Ferrimagnet
